repnme.cdata!:
Latin America and the Caribbean - Central
            America Integration System for Regional HIV/AIDS Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Central America Integration System
            for a Regional HIV/AIDS Project development objective is to
            provide knowledge, and tools to decision makers in all
            countries in the region, to manage and control HIV/AIDS, and
            other opportunistic infections. Component 1 - Regional
            Laboratory and contingencies, will support the establishment
            of a regional laboratory to implement highly-specialized
            functions, as a single regional institution. These functions
            include: a) acting as a regional reference diagnostic; b)
            becoming a specialized regional training center on HIV/AIDS
            related technologies for laboratory workers; c) developing
            information systems for laboratories specialized in HIV/AIDS
            tests; d) carrying out specialized research on technologies
            for testing HIV/AIDS viruses; e) becoming the regional
            center for quality control of HIV/AIDS national
            laboratories; and f) assessing and transferring technologies
            to national laboratories. Component 2 - Epidemiological
            Surveillance - will support the implementation of a regional
            second-generation epidemiological surveillance system, to
            enable improved characterization of the nature of the
            HIV/AIDS epidemic in Central America. The system will
            include an integrated information system with country
            information, and, will disseminate information throughout
            the region, periodic HIV surveillance in high-risk groups,
            behavioral risk factor surveillance, and a training program.
            Data would be disaggregated, at least, by age, gender, and
            ethnicity, and as possible, by population mobility.
            Component 3 - Strengthening the Regional Response Capacity
            will increase the harmonization of legal and institutional
            frameworks needed to scale-up strategic interventions, in
            response to the HIV/AIDS epidemic. It will also strengthen
            leadership and political commitment leading to a Regional
            Action Plan with common policies and strategies, addressing
            the epidemic in a coordinated way. This component will
            support shared best practices on prevention and
            comprehensive care, including desk reviews, and workshops at
            the regional level with health and non-health institutions,
            and civil society representatives, to examine the HIVIAIDS
            legal framework for civil rights, integrated treatment
            access, and drug and lab supplies regulations. Component 4 -
            Prevention in Mobile Populations - will focus on the
            particularly vulnerable to HIV/AIDS, i.e., mobile
            populations, considered to be a key factor in the
            epidemic's spread. Prevention programs focusing on
            these populations are still few, and work at a small scale.
            The main actions are: a) strengthening coordination across
            sectors, both at the country and regional levels, organizing
            periodic meetings and workshops of key actors and agencies;
            (b) providing continuity to successful prevention
            subprojects, and supporting the development of new
            preventive interventions, through a competitive process
            among sponsors, mainly nongovernmental organizations (NGOs)
            or a group of NGOs working in more than one country; and, c)
            strengthening human resources capacity involved in the
            sector, through the provision of training programs. Finally,
            Component 5 - Project Management will support project
            administration, structure and practices. Moreover, it will
            finance computer and office equipment, and furniture, and,
            technical assistance of long-term technical consultants in
            the Project Coordination Unit.

repnme.cdata!:
Central America - Regional HIV/AIDS Project
            : indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
In light of the presence of indigenous
            populations, and afro-descendent groups within the Regional
            HIV/AIDS Project in Central America, it is necessary the
            project comprises an Indigenous Peoples Plan (IPP). The IPP
            will ensure that these groups benefit from project
            implementation in an equitable, and culturally adequate
            manner, and ensure as well their active participation,
            including that of nongovernmental organizations, and
            community groups - in particular, health providers - for a
            successful project implementation. The IPP consists of two
            stages: the first, is a review of demographic,
            anthropological, legal and institutional aspects, as well as
            the HIV/AIDS epidemiological incidence among those groups,
            supported by the participating countries' ministries of
            health; the second stage complements the first, through
            consultations with affected populations. The study concludes
            there is no official data on the epidemic's incidence
            among these groups, given statistics do not register ethnic
            variables. Nevertheless, for the purpose of this project,
            the incidence of HIV/AIDS was mapped geographically. Given
            the increasing numbers of the epidemic in Central America,
            it is suggested to include ethnic and gender variables in
            the epidemic's prevention systems (financed by the
            project under the second component). Furthermore, given the
            current traditional health methods among indigenous
            populations, and ethnic groups in health prevention, it is
            recommended to review traditional networks, so as to build
            capacities, to be able to collaborate in the prevention,
            care, and assistance to HIV/AIDS affected people. It is
            important to educate health workers, and community networks
            on the rights and duties of affected people, because, as
            certain rights are being questioned (e.g., confidentiality)
            conducing to a negative reaction, the right precautions are
            not being considered, but the fact remains that people
            should be informed and educated on the use of their
            obligations. Two major obstacles hamper the distribution and
            marketing of condoms: the Church opposition, maintaining its
            use engenders sexual promiscuity, and, the
            ("Machista" male) idiosyncrasy that its use
            promotes infidelity. In addition, two major groups
            identified, particularly in Honduras, are HIV/AIDS affected
            orphans - who need epidemiological monitoring, as well as
            social protection - and house wifes infected by their own
            husbands. Workshops are recommended (to be included under
            the third component) where epidemic diagnoses within
            indigenous populations, and afro-descendant groups, should
            be discussed as part of current strategies (lessons learned,
            and success stories), supported by regional partnerships
            with nongovernmental organizations (to be financed under the
            fourth component).

repnme.cdata!:
Latin America and Caribbean Region -
            Central America HIV/AIDS Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Central America HIV/AIDS Project for
            Latin America and Caribbean Region aims to provide knowledge
            and tools to decision makers in all countries in the region
            to manage and control HIV/AIDS and other opportunistic
            infections. The Gorgas Institute has prepared an
            environmental impact assessment study to cover the expansion
            in 2001. This plan covers activities related to the
            expansion of and optimization of medical services to be
            provided for local population. The Institute has its own
            health waste care management plan for service expansion,
            which includes: sorting, handling, transportation,
            immunization and disposal of health care waste. Besides the
            current health waste management plan currently under
            implementation, the institute has decided to expand and
            organize its procedures to manage the expected demand of
            health care waste. The new version includes estimates on the
            increase on health care waste due to the new services to be
            provided. The health care waste management plan focuses on a
            set of procedures to enhance the quality of management of
            new volumes and sources of waste. As a standard practice,
            the plan will include training and awareness activities for
            involved personnel. Indicators to monitor its implementation
            will also be developed and enforced through Bank supervision
            activities. As a practice the Gorgas Institute has its own
            procedures on how to handle construction activities. This
            plan is very comprehensive and aims at protecting the
            quality of the surrounding environment.
